articles.content:
The Public Baths of Ancient Pompeii Were Actually Pretty Gross—Until the Romans Built an Aqueduct
Hygienic conditions were poor in the city’s older bathing facilities, a new study reveals. The analysis sheds light on Pompeii’s water systems and residents’ bathing habits
Pompeii’s public bathing pools were filled with sweat, skin oil, urine and other bodily fluids from visitors until a Roman aqueduct improved the water quality.
That’s the conclusion researchers have reached after investigating the layers of historical mineral deposits left behind in Pompeii’s public baths, according to a new paper published January 12 in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.
Each layer of mineral deposits has its own chemical signature, which offers clues about the source of the water, as well as how it was used. The scientists used these deposits as a time capsule of sorts, exploring their geochemistry to shed light on the evolution of Pompeii’s water system—and residents’ bathing experiences—over time.
When Mount Vesuvius erupted in 79 C.E., Pompeii was a Roman colony. But before the Romans took over in 80 B.C.E., it was inhabited by the Samnite people, a group of tribes with their own language and culture.
During the Samnite occupation, Pompeii had at least two public bathing pools, which were filled by enslaved individuals who used a system of wheels and buckets to draw water up from deep wells—a slow and labor-intensive process. By the researchers’ estimates, the system would have only pulled up between 238 and 1,321 gallons of well water per hour, meaning the pools were likely refilled only once or twice a day, reports New Scientist’s Colin Barras.
That slow rate of replenishment likely helps explain why researchers found evidence of organic matter in the pools—but not in the wells themselves. While bathers scrubbed and soaked, the water in the public baths became contaminated with their grime. The conditions were “far from ideal,” lead author Gül Sürmelihindi, an archaeologist at Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz in Germany, says in a statement.
Alexander Meddings, an independent historian who was not involved with the research, puts it more bluntly. “Bathers would have been polluting the water with a whole array of festering wounds, peeing in the pools, sweating after their workouts and scraping off their dead skin,” he tells BBC Science Focus’ Hatty Willmoth. “I expect a fairly common sight would have been a cloudy, floating layer of scum.”
The experience, he notes, would have been “pretty grim by today’s standards.”
However, several decades after the Romans took over Pompeii, they built an aqueduct to supply the city with fresh water from a nearby natural spring. The aqueduct, which the researchers calculate brought in 44,117 gallons of water per hour, made the city’s public baths much more hygienic.
Quick fact: The triumph of the Roman aqueduct
- Surviving aqueducts that once supplied water to the Roman Empire can be found in countries such as Spain, Greece, France and Turkey.
- The city of Rome alone had 11 aqueducts.
When the scientists investigated historical mineral deposits from the Roman aqueduct era, they found evidence of much less organic matter—which suggests that the water in the pools was cleaner, though likely still not pristine.
“Visiting the baths must have been a noisy, lively and possibly smelly experience—more a social event than anything else,” study co-author Cees Passchier, a geoscientist at Johannes Gutenberg University Mainz, tells BBC Science Focus.
The aqueduct may have made bathing a more hygienic experience for Pompeians. But this sophisticated new technology was far from perfect, the researchers write. In addition to supplying water to the baths, the aqueduct provided drinking water to many Pompeii residents. But the water was distributed throughout the city via a series of pipes made of lead—now a well-known neurotoxin that can cause serious health problems.
Over time, the water quality probably improved—and Pompeians were likely exposed to less pollution from the pipes. That’s because, as more and more water flowed through the system, it left behind minerals that encrusted the insides of the pipes, which eventually prevented much of the poisonous lead from being leached out, the researchers write in the paper. However, any time the city replaced the pipes with new ones, the contamination probably got worse again.
Pompeii’s poorer and working-class residents, who relied almost exclusively on public fountains for their drinking water, were probably the most affected by the lead contamination, per New Scientist. The wealthy elite, meanwhile, likely had rainwater-capture systems on their large homes, so they didn’t end up drinking as much lead-filled water.
Looking ahead, the researchers are eager to conduct similar studies throughout the Roman Empire. Though mineral deposits are “very boring-looking,” they “actually are a great source of information” about how individuals lived, bathed and drank, Passchier tells Chemical & Engineering News’ Fionna Samuels.

articles.title: Contents of a Wolf Pup’s Stomach From 14,400 Years Ago Are Teaching Researchers About the Lives of the Last Woolly Rhinos
articles.author: Redação

Analysis of woolly rhinoceros DNA recovered from the permafrost-preserved...
articles.content:
Contents of a Wolf Pup’s Stomach From 14,400 Years Ago Are Teaching Researchers About the Lives of the Last Woolly Rhinos
Analysis of woolly rhinoceros DNA recovered from the permafrost-preserved wolf further hints that the Ice Age beasts went extinct because of a sudden shift in the climate
Roughly 14,400 years ago, a two-month-old wolf pup in what’s now northern Siberia chowed down on her last meal—a bit of wagtail, some woolly rhinoceros, a few tufts of arctic bluegrass. Not long after, the young pup and her sister died, possibly because a landslide collapsed on their den. Their bodies were preserved in the permafrost until researchers discovered them in the 21st century.
Now, scientists say they have successfully reconstructed the complete set of genetic instructions, or genome, of the woolly rhinoceros that one of the “Tumat puppies” feasted upon before her untimely death. The ancient rhino DNA—preserved inside the wolf pup’s stomach for millennia—is revealing fresh insights into how the Ice Age beasts may have gone extinct, researchers report in a study published January 14 in the journal Genome Biology and Evolution.
“For us, many, many, many thousands of years later to have uncovered these beautifully preserved mummified wolf puppies, looked into their stomach contents and found this piece of woolly rhinoceros tissue—which has then shed light on an entirely different species—is very unique and cool,” says study co-author Edana Lord, an evolutionary biologist now at the Botanic Gardens of Sydney who conducted the research while at Stockholm University, to New Scientist’s James Woodford.
Researchers discovered the first wolf pup in 2011 near the present-day settlement of Tumat, Siberia. They unearthed the second in 2015. Both young animals were remarkably well-preserved, with their skin, fur and teeth still intact.
When researchers dissected the pups, they realized their stomachs were also still full of food. The mix contained a chunk of woolly rhinoceros flesh that still had yellowish hair on it.
“The tissue was so intact, it looked like the wolf had just swallowed it before it died,” says study co-author Camilo Chacón-Duque, an evolutionary geneticist at Uppsala University in Sweden who also conducted the research while at Stockholm University, to National Geographic’s Jack Tamisea.
Woolly rhinoceroses went extinct just a few centuries after the wolf pups died, but the cause of their demise remains a mystery. Some of the leading theories are climate change, inbreeding and pressure from human hunting. The researchers wondered if the partially digested fragment might offer any clues.
But first, they had to extract the woolly rhinoceros’ DNA—a highly challenging feat. The team spent months collecting samples from different parts of the fragment, taking care to avoid genetic contamination from the wolf pup. They used a scalpel to cut through the hide, which was dry and tough, similar to a piece of beef jerky, Chacón-Duque tells the New York Times’ Ari Daniel. They sequenced the highest-quality DNA they could extract, then merged the results to cover the entire genome.
They compared this genome with two previously sequenced woolly rhino genomes—one that was around 18,000 years old and another about 49,000 years old. The more recent woolly rhino that had been eaten by the wolf pups—a female, their investigation revealed—showed no signs of inbreeding or genetic decline compared with the older specimens, which suggests the species was healthy not long before vanishing.
Since the species was nearing extinction at the time, “one might assume the last lineages would have small populations and were highly inbred,” Nathan Wales, an archaeologist at the University of York in England who was not involved with the research, writes in an email to CNN’s Katie Hunt. “But this well-established analysis shows that, at a genetic level, the population looked stable.”
This finding, the researchers argue, further supports the idea that a sudden outside factor, such as a shift in the climate, caused the species to die out. Wales calls this a “reasonable conclusion.”
A few centuries after the woolly rhinos went extinct, the northern hemisphere went through a period of warming known as the Bølling–Allerød interstadial. This changing climate may not have killed off the rhinos directly but, rather, caused changes to their environment that made it impossible for them to survive.
For instance, perhaps warmer temperatures or wetter conditions wiped out the woolly rhinoceroses’ main food source, Laura Epp, an environmental genomicist at the University of Konstanz in Germany who wasn’t involved in the study, tells the Times. A warmer climate may also have benefitted early humans, so hunting or human-driven habitat loss could also have been factors, Advait Jukar, a vertebrate paleontologist at the Florida Museum of Natural History who also wasn’t involved in the new research, tells National Geographic.
Another possibility? Some catastrophic event—like a natural disaster or a virus—could have led to the animals’ demise, which is how the last woolly mammoths may have died.
Did you know? The deaths of the last woolly mammoths
Chacón-Duque and colleagues previously studied how the last woolly mammoths, a population on Wrangel Island northeast of Siberia, died. Although the animals seemed to have low genetic diversity and genetic diseases, the researchers suspect a sudden unlucky incident, such as a novel virus, a volcanic eruption or a tundra fire, ultimately did them in.
Either way, the fate of the woolly rhinoceros might serve as a cautionary tale for conservationists working to protect modern species. The creatures seemed totally fine but still vanished within a few hundred years—which suggests even successful species may only be a few generations away from extinction.
“Just because a living species on the surface looks OK genetically doesn’t mean it’s not vulnerable,” says Mick Westbury, an evolutionary biologist at the Technical University of Denmark who was not involved with the research, to NBC News’ Evan Bush.

articles.content:
All Nine of Jan van Eyck’s Surviving Portraits Are Coming Together for the Very First Time in History
The Northern Renaissance painter’s innovative techniques altered the course of art history. An upcoming exhibition in London brings together his 15th-century portraits from collections across Europe
On the National Gallery’s website, the most-visited painting page is devoted to the Arnolfini Portrait. According to the London museum, this painting of a married couple, created by Jan van Eyck in 1434, “must be one of the most famous and intriguing paintings in the world.”
The figure on the left is likely Giovanni di Nicolao di Arnolfini, an Italian merchant dressed in dark robes and a large hat. On the right is his wife, clothed in a vibrant green gown. The painting’s details and techniques have stunned critics for centuries. Art historian Ernst Gombrich once called the Arnolfini Portrait “a simple corner of the real world … fixed on to a panel as if by magic.”
Born in what’s now Belgium around the 1390s, van Eyck is known as the father of oil painting. Now, all nine of van Eyck’s surviving portraits are being united for the first time. “Van Eyck: The Portraits” will be on view at the National Gallery in London this fall. The collected works make up nearly half of the painter’s surviving oeuvre.
Fun fact: Shoes in the Arnolfini Portrait
Two pairs of pattens, or overshoes worn on top of flimsy footwear, are visible in this portrait.
“[Portraiture burst] onto the scene fully formed in the 1430s under the brush of Jan van Eyck,” says Emma Capron, the museum’s curator of early Netherlandish and German paintings, in a statement. “None of the stylized likenesses that preceded his work would pass as a portrait today: You would not recognize their sitters if you walked by them on the street.”
Before the Renaissance, most artists’ depictions of people weren’t very lifelike. Instead, they often had exaggerated, flat features. “Van Eyck’s were the first faces that were genuinely lifelike,” writes the London Times’ Ed Conway. “These were not just icons; they were humans. Were the couple from the Arnolfini Portrait, probably his most famous such work, to pass you in the street, you would have no trouble recognizing them.”
Van Eyck died around 1441, and his only verified portraits that exist today are from the last decade or so of his life. In 1432, van Eyck and his brother, artist Hubert van Eyck, painted the Ghent Altarpiece for St. Bavo’s Cathedral in Ghent, Belgium. The artwork is sometimes known as “the first major oil painting.”
“Van Eyck is one of the pillars of the National Gallery’s collection and a foundational figure in the European history of art,” Gabriele Finaldi, the National Gallery’s director, says in the statement. “The portraits reflect a remarkable sensitivity to his sitters and an astounding technical virtuosity in their execution.”
The portraits on display will include Margaret, the Artist’s Wife, which dates to 1439 and depicts van Eyck’s spouse in a red dress and white head covering. Besides this portrait, the museum will display Portrait of a Man (Self-Portrait?), dated to 1433 and thought to depict the artist himself. The piece, which shows a prosperous van Eyck clothed in a “flamboyant red hat,” was recently conserved, per the museum.
The show will also display van Eyck’s Portrait of a Man (circa 1440) alongside the Arnolfini Portrait, as both are thought to depict the same man. The imported oranges sitting on the windowsill in the double portrait reveal that the Arnolfinis were quite wealthy, as Artnet’s Jo Lawson-Tancred writes.
Van Eyck’s realism preceded that of Italy’s Leonardo da Vinci and Michelangelo, who rose to prominence about half a century after the painter’s death. Leonardo dissected roughly 30 cadavers to learn more about the human body, aiming to improve the precision of his drawings. Michelangelo also participated in some dissections, which informed his vivid anatomical nudes.
Did van Eyck’s work also benefit from advances in science and technology? The English painter David Hockney once suggested that van Eyck used newly developed glass lenses to filter and project a scene onto a canvas, which he then traced, per the Times. However, many art historians dispute this theory.
“These portraits’ ability to baffle by their precision and liveliness is intact today,” Capron says in the statement. “Their impact belies their intimate scale. We are really proud and grateful to our lenders to be able to show van Eyck’s pioneering contribution to the rise of portraiture in this once-in-a-lifetime exhibition.”
“Van Eyck: The Portraits” will be on view at the National Gallery in London from November 21, 2026, to April 11, 2027.

Greenland Sharks Can Survive for Centuries—and Maintain Long-Lasting Vision, Despite Living in the Dark
The long-living sharks aren’t as blind as once thought and have DNA repair mechanisms that may help prevent their vision from degrading, a study suggests
Greenland sharks—the longest-living vertebrates in the world—dwell in the deep, frigid waters of the Arctic and North Atlantic for up to roughly 400 years. Scientists have long suspected that the creatures were basically blind due to pesky eye parasites and spending their lengthy lives in such a dimly lit place.
New research has found, however, that the animals seem to have surprisingly good vision and DNA repair mechanisms to maintain it throughout their lifetimes. The findings, published on January 5 in the journal Nature Communications, not only shed light on a long-lasting visual system but could also lead to ways to prevent human sight problems, such as macular degeneration.
Fun fact: Life of a Greenland shark
These marine animals grow slowly, less than half an inch per year, but they can reach lengths of more than 20 feet. They can swim around 10,000 feet below the ocean’s surface.
Evolutionary biologist Lily Fogg says that the study came about after John Fleng Steffensen, a marine biologist at the University of Copenhagen who recently died, offered her and her colleagues some specimens from his other work. Steffensen previously helped discover the creatures’ centuries-long lifespan via eye samples.
“He said, ‘I’ve got these eyes, would you like to do a study on them?’” Fogg, of the University of Basel in Switzerland, tells Mongabay’s Bobby Bascomb. “And we said, ‘Why not? That’s a great opportunity.’ If they’re going in the bin, then that would just be a waste.”
The eyeballs were then sent out to the researchers. “I opened the package, and there was a giant, 200-year-old eyeball sitting on dry ice just staring back at me,” recalls study co-author Emily Tom, a physiologist at the University of California, Irvine, in a statement.
Overall, the research team examined eyeballs from ten Greenland sharks that were caught off the coast of western Greenland between 2020 and 2024 and ranged in age from about 100 to 134 years old. An analysis revealed no signs of degeneration in the light-sensitive parts of the old organs, and the sharks’ eye parasites didn’t seem to interfere with the animals’ vision.
Additionally, most vertebrates have two types of light-sensitive eye cells: cones, which differentiate color and work well in bright light, and rods, which don’t detect colors but work well in dim light. But the Greenland sharks had only rod cells, which means they see in black and white, the team found.
“[As a Greenland shark] you don’t have high resolution,” study co-author Dorota Skowronska-Krawczyk, a physiologist at the University of California, Irvine, tells the Australian Broadcasting Corporation’s Peter de Kruijff. “You see light and darkness, but you really don’t see the shapes very well, or you cannot distinguish probably fast movements.”
What’s more, a close look at genetic material from some of the eyeballs hinted that the secret to the sharks’ long-lasting vision might be the genes ERCC1 and ERCC4. They code for proteins that help repair DNA and seem to be important for maintaining eyesight. Only shark species with the longest lives have the ERCC1 gene, the team found, and Greenland sharks had an elevated amount of ERCC4 likely being made into proteins compared to other sharks.
“The high expression of DNA repair genes suggests a powerful molecular mechanism that helps maintain retinal health over centuries—a cool finding,” Laura Ryan, a comparative neurobiologist at Macquarie University in Australia who was not involved in the research, tells the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
The researchers suspect their work could pave the way for future work relevant to human health, such as how to avoid age-related vision loss and eye diseases like macular degeneration and glaucoma.
“We can learn so much about vision and longevity from long-lived species like the Greenland shark,” Tom says in the statement.
